metadata.case_name: Raja Narayanlal Bansilal v. Maneck P. Mistry & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant Raja Narayanlal Bansilal is the Managing Agent of Harinagar Sugar Mills Limited.
On November 15, 1954, Registrar wrote to the mills under s.137(6) of Indian Companies Act, 1913, that business was carried on in fraud and called for information (Ex. A).

On April 15, 1955, Registrar made report (Ex. AA) to Central Government under s.137(5), suspecting fraud by appellant via Bansilal Uchant Account, purchases of Harpur Farm (Rs.19,200 between 1942-1951) and Bhavanipur Farm (Rs.39,300), utilising company property for personal gain, recommending investigation under s.138.
On November 1, 1955, Central Government appointed first respondent Maneck P. Mistry as inspector under s.138(4) (Ex. B) to investigate from incorporation, with instructions (Ex. BB).
Inspector wrote to appellant to examine him on oath under s.140(2) (Ex. C).
Companies Act, 1913 repealed by Companies Act, 1956 effective April 1, 1956.

On July 26, 1956, Central Government approved under s.239(2) of new Act investigation into appellant's affairs, personal books, and three concerns: M/s. Narayanlal Bansilal, Shangrila Food Products Limited, Harinagar Cane Farm.
On May 9, May 16, May 29, June 29, 1957, inspector served four notices (Ex. E) on appellant to attend for examination on oath under s.240(2), produce 12 items of books/accounts relating to company.
Appellant filed petition No. 201 of 1957 in Bombay High Court under Art.226 for certiorari, prohibition against notices, examination, investigation under ss.239/240.
Grounds: Inspector appointed under old Act lacks jurisdiction under new Act; ss.239/240 violate Art.20(3) and Art.14.
Mr. Justice K.T. Desai rejected petition.
Appeal No.28/1958 in Bombay High Court dismissed, agreeing with single judge.
Certificate granted, appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether first respondent (inspector appointed under old Act) has jurisdiction to exercise powers under ss.239/240 of new Act.
Whether s.240 violates Art.20(3) by compelling self-incrimination.
Whether ss.239/240 violate Art.14 by denying protections under Evidence Act s.132 and CrPC s.161.

petitioner_arguments.text: Inspector appointed under old Act s.138 lacks jurisdiction under new Act ss.239/240 as powers are wider ('draconian').
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Companies Act 1956 ss.645,646; old Act ss.137,138,140

petitioner_arguments.text: S.240 violates Art.20(3) as compels appellant to be witness against himself; 'accused of any offence' to be liberally construed; relies on US 5th Amendment cases.
Ss.239/240 violate Art.14 by denying witness protections under Evidence Act s.132, CrPC s.161(1),(2).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Art.14; Indian Evidence Act s.132; CrPC s.161

respondent_arguments.text: Resisted pleas; inspector deemed appointed under new Act by s.645; no violation of Art.20(3) or 14.

court_reasoning.text: S.645 deems appointment under old s.138(4) as under new s.235; s.646 is additional saving, not exception to s.645; inspector has jurisdiction under s.240.

Art.20(3) applies only if 'accused of any offence'; requires formal accusation leading to prosecution. Inspector's inquiry is fact-finding into company affairs, not accusatory; no accusation at notice stage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Investigation begins to examine management irregularities, not with accusation; consistent with precedents like M.P. Sharma.

court_reasoning.text: Ss.239/240 reasonable classification for company managers distinct from individuals; protects creditors/contributories; no Art.14 violation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification based on intelligible differentia with rational relation to object.

holdings.text: Inspector appointed under old Act deemed under new Act by s.645; has jurisdiction to issue notices under s.240.
S.240 does not violate Art.20(3); appellant not 'accused of any offence' during inquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maqbool Hussain v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.20(2) construction; proceedings must be criminal before court.

precedents_cited.case_name: A. Venkataraman v. Union of India

precedents_cited.relevance: Art.20(3) requires formal accusation; search not compelled testimony.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thomas Dana v. State of Punjab
Mohammed Dastagir v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.20(3) not violated if not accused and not compelled.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Justice Tendolkar
Hearts of Oak Assurance Co. v. Attorney General

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for initial investigation and appointment.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of inspector, savings on repeal; upheld as valid.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Effect of repeal subject to ss.645-657.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Witness protection contrasted but classification justified.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Bombay High Court; inspector has jurisdiction under new Act; ss.239/240 do not violate Arts.14 or 20(3).

key_quotes.text: "No person accused of any offence shall be compelled to be a witness against himself."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Art.20(3) quoted; protection requires formal accusation.

key_quotes.text: The constitutional guarantee is available to a person against whom a formal accusation relating to the commission of an offence has been leveled.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From M.P. Sharma; key test for Art.20(3).

key_quotes.text: The investigation carried on by the inspectors is not more than the work of a fact-finding commission.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Nature of company inquiry not accusatory.
